author: Coreena Ford
title: Metrocentre and Eldon Square owners intu praise centres for strong trading
text:
Metrocentre and Eldon Square owners intu praise centres for strong trading 14:11, 28 Jul 2016 The final restaurant at intu Eldon Square's new dining zone is also due to be announced within weeks Shares Get business news by email How the entrance to intu Eldon Square will look when work on the dining zone has finished 
The Metrocentre and Eldon Square are among the star performers which have steered their owner Intu to strong half-year results. 
Intu Properties, which owns the Newcastle and Gateshead complexes, has posted strong figures for the first half of 2016, with like-for-like net rental income rising by 7.5% in the period as a result of increased occupancy, improving rental levels from new lettings and rent reviews. 
The firm, which is the UK’s leading owner, manager and developer of prime regional shopping centres with a growing presence in Spain, said it signed 98 long-term leases for £17m new annual rent in the period, including 82 in the UK. 
During the six months to June 30, the firm completed the new £17m restaurant development at intu Metrocentre, and said it is on course to open intu Eldon Square’s new dining zone Grey’s Quarter this autumn. 
The firm will open 20 new restaurants at the Newcastle complex, which has 140 stores, with 19 pre-let. Chief finance officer Matthew Roberts said contracts should soon be exchanged with the final restaurant operator. 
Mr Roberts said: “We have seen some interest in the last site at Grey’s Quarter and should exchange contracts in the next few weeks. 
“The two centres are trading very well. Eldon Square is now at 99% occupancy and we only have a couple of empty units. 
“And we’ve seen good performance at the Metrocentre which is 93%, so both are trading strongly and there is good footfall so we are very pleased with what’s happening there.” 
The figures only cover one week of trading post Brexit vote, and directors said it is too early for the full consequences of the EU vote to emerge. 
However since June 23, footfall has been in line with the first six months, and more firms have signed up to take on units across the firm’s 18 UK centres, suggesting its operations will not be affected by the referendum result. 
Mr Roberts added: “We’ve seen no noticeable decline in business and in terms of lettings, 27 deals have been completed since June 27, some in the last week or so.” 
In a review of the UK market, the firm said it was seeing retailers continue expansion and upsizing in prime high footfall retail destinations, including Primark at intu Metrocentre which has expanded its unit. 
International retailers are also expanding into the UK centre, with the likes of Smiggle, Tiger and Kiko opening up shops. 
Retailer administrations in the period including 10 BHS units and two Austin Reed, amounting to around 1% of intu’s rent roll. 
Intu’s success has been announced on the same day that a new report revealed “dramatic” structural change in the retail industry. 
More stores have also closed, driven by the food sector, according to the figures for the second quarter of the year by the British Retail Consortium (BRC). 
The number of workers fell by 2.4% compared with the same period last year, with “deep declines” reported in April and May.
